awd_abstract_narration:
Nuclear and particle physics aim to understand fundamental parameters and laws of nature at subatomic distances. Among such parameters are the masses of elementary particles: quarks and leptons. Quarks are particles that interact via the strong force -- this force binds them together in an atomic nucleus. Leptons do not feel this force; the most familiar example of a lepton is the electron that is bound to the nucleus by the electromagnetic interaction. A more exotic lepton is the neutrino, which has no electric charge and interacts only weakly. Yet, this elusive particle is proving to be a crucial link in our search for new physics. Exquisite experimental measurements over the last two decades have revealed that the neutrinos have small but nonzero masses, but the fundamental understanding of the quarks and lepton masses remains elusive. In this broader context, this project will provide the theoretical foundations needed in support of experimental efforts designed to measure with high accuracy the masses of the neutrinos and light quarks. This project will provide excellent training ground for students.

An important challenge in nuclear and particle physics concerns the description of the strong force at low energy with the accuracy matching the experimental level of precision. Specifically, the aim of this project is to understand the three-pion system. This system is the final state of the decay of the eta-meson that is used for the light quark mass determination.This system is also an intermediate state of the neutrino-nucleus interaction and therefore plays an essential role in interpreting neutrino experiments. The PI and her collaborators will develop an analytical framework to accurately model three-pion interactions, based on the methods of chiral perturbation theory and dispersive techniques. This will support state-of-the-art nuclear physics experiments at Thomas Jefferson Laboratory, particularly GlueX or CLAS, as well as the upcoming precision neutrino-nucleus scattering experiments at Fermilab and worldwide.

por.por_cntn:
The aim of this project was to develop the necessary theoretical tools to be able to extract certain fundamental parameters of nature at subatomic distances, namely the masses of quarks and neutrinos. Quarks are particles that interact via the strong force -- this force binds them together in an atomic nucleus. Leptons do not feel this force; the most familiar example of a lepton is the electron that is bound to the nucleus by the electromagnetic interaction. A more exotic lepton is the neutrino, which has no electric charge and interacts only weakly. Yet, this elusive particle is proving to be a crucial link in our search for new laws of nature. At present, we have no fundamental understanding why the masses of all the quarks and leptons are what they are; their values are just parameters that must be extracted from data. Yet, it is hoped that once they are measured very precisely, it may be possible to understand the underlying principles behind them.
In this project, we have built the theoretical foundations necessary to correctly extract the underlying physics from experimental results.

A common challenge in both cases is to be able to describe the strong force at low energy with the accuracy matching the experimental level of precision. Specifically, we made significant progress in our understanding of the three-pion system. A pion is a meson state made of a quark and an anti-quark which is created at low energy in strongly interacting systems.

We successfully described the three-pion system using a combination of two theoretical techniques. One is known as the dispersive analysis. It uses model-independent constraints coming from general properties of scattering amplitudes, such as analyticity, unitarity and crossing symmetry. The second one is called the chiral perturbation theory. It is an effective field theory describing strong interactions at low energies.

By systematically developing and applying these two techniques, we were able to derive the most accurate and up-to-date experimental determination of the up-down quark mass difference. As input, we use precision measurements of the eta meson decay to a three-pion system. The data which was taken at the KLOE experiment in Frascati, Italy and at the MAMI experiment in Mainz, Germany included both charged pion and neutral pion final states. Promising experimental results combining both channels are also expected from Jefferson Laboratory in the US.

An alternative method of extracting these masses uses the approach of lattice Quantum ChromoDynamics (QCD). This method uses large supercomputing resources and involves different theoretical uncertainties. Our results are at present the only way to subject the lattice QCD results for this mass difference to experimental test.

Additionally, we have been able to solve a long-standing (30 years old) puzzle concerning the slope of the neutral-pion channel on the so-called Dalitz plot, which previous papers could not correctly predict (not even its sign) using the techniques of chiral perturbation theory also. Our calculation, which agrees with experiment and is of comparable accuracy, includes the relevant isospin breaking and electromagnetic contributions required by the level of precision reached experimentally. A careful assessment of the uncertainties has been performed making this analysis the reference in the field.

The second part of the project was dedicated to applying these precision techniques and high level standards to neutrino physics. The aim was to improve the hadronic physics background necessary for extracting fundamental parameters from the next generation of neutrino experiments, particularly neutrino masses and mixing parameters.

Existing models of neutrino-nucleon interactions at the energies of modern laboratory neutrino experiments are characterized by a number of simplistic, untested assumptions. In the course of this project, we have calculated the 3-pion contribution at low energies to the axial form factor of the nucleon. This process is fundamental for understanding the interactions in the energy range relevant to several modern experiments, particularly those at the short-baseline program at Fermilab in the US. We have also investigated the lattice QCD results on the axial form factor, building a bridge with the current experimental needs in terms of the neutrino-nucleus cross sections. This works has opened new avenues to future improvements in the axial form factor determination combining lattice QCD results with analytical methods.

In the course of the project we trained 3 undergraduate and 3 graduate students, as well as 2 postdoctoral fellows.
